question.task: Write a short reflective essay (no more than 0.5 of a page) on the most transformative insight you have gained during your studies at UWC.
question.context: This could be from BDC334 or from another course, fieldwork, lab work, or independent study.
requirements: What specific idea, skill, or experience changed how you think about science or the world?
Why did this insight matter to you personally or intellectually?
How did it challenge or overturn any preconceptions you once held?
How has it influenced the way you now approach questions as a developing scientist?
constraints: Avoid clichés (e.g., 'as a biologist, I have come to learn that all of nature is connected') or broad generalisations.

criteria.name: Specificity of Example
criteria.description: Concreteness and detail of the transformative experience or insight

indicators: No specific course, experience, or concept mentioned
Responses that could be written without attending university
Names specific course or experience but lacks detail
Some concrete elements but insufficient elaboration
Partial development of the transformative moment
Beginning to show personal engagement but underdeveloped

scoring_bands.descriptor: Clear, detailed example of a concept, method, or experience.
indicators: Specific course, lab work, fieldwork, or concept clearly identified
Rich descriptive detail about the learning experience
Clear articulation of what exactly was learned
Concrete examples that demonstrate genuine engagement

criteria.name: Depth of Reflection
criteria.description: Quality of introspective analysis and personal engagement

indicators: Statements of fact rather than reflection
No exploration of personal meaning or significance

scoring_bands.descriptor: Some reflection on why it mattered.
Deep, personal or intellectual engagement with the idea.
indicators: Rich introspective analysis of learning process
Clear articulation of personal or intellectual significance
Genuine emotional or intellectual engagement demonstrated

criteria.name: Transformation & Preconceptions
criteria.description: Evidence of changed thinking and intellectual development

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of change in thinking.

indicators: Acknowledges some change but lacks specificity

scoring_bands.descriptor: Clear evidence of how preconceptions were challenged and replaced.
indicators: Recognition of how new understanding replaced old ideas

criteria.name: Clarity & Authenticity
criteria.description: Quality of writing and genuine personal voice

indicators: Generic responses that lack personal character
Engaging narrative that reflects genuine experience

grading_instructions.approach: Assess authenticity and depth of personal reflection rather than technical knowledge
assessment_priorities: Authenticity of personal voice and experience
Specificity and concreteness of learning examples
warning_signs: Generic statements about nature being connected
Lack of concrete examples or experiences
Responses that could apply to any student in any discipline
Manufactured emotional language without genuine engagement
Absence of specific UWC courses, faculty, or experiences
positive_indicators: Specific methodological insights from particular courses
Personal intellectual challenges described with detail
Connection between insight and future scientific approach
Evidence of struggle or difficulty in learning process
Specific references to UWC experiences, courses, or faculty
Recognition of personal growth and development
common_clichés_to_avoid: As a biologist, I have come to learn that all of nature is connected
Science has opened my eyes to the wonders of the natural world
I never realized how complex/beautiful/amazing nature is
This course taught me that everything is interconnected
I learned to think outside the box
My perspective on life has completely changed
authentic_reflection_markers: Specific moments of confusion or clarity described
Particular assignments, experiments, or readings mentioned
Names of specific concepts, theories, or methods
Recognition of personal biases or assumptions challenged
Concrete examples of how thinking has changed in practice
Evidence of ongoing questioning and uncertainty
grading_instructions.length_consideration: Maximum 0.5 page requires concise, focused reflection rather than comprehensive coverage

content_requirements: What was done well/correctly in relation to this criterion
What was incorrect, missing, or inadequately addressed

suggested_improvements.heading: Suggested improvements
suggested_improvements.content: Single paragraph outlining specific steps the student can take to improve their reflective writing
suggested_improvements.focus: Actionable advice for developing authentic self-reflection and metacognitive awareness

final_mark.calculation: Sum of all criterion marks converted to percentage out of 10 total marks

feedback_sequence: Criterion 1: Specificity of Example feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3
Criterion 2: Depth of Reflection feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3
Criterion 3: Transformation & Preconceptions feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3
Criterion 4: Clarity & Authenticity feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 1

special_considerations.authenticity_assessment: Distinguish between genuine personal reflection and manufactured responses that mimic reflective writing conventions
special_considerations.cliché_detection: Identify formulaic language patterns that indicate superficial engagement with the reflective process
special_considerations.institutional_specificity: Verify that responses demonstrate genuine engagement with UWC learning environment rather than generic university experiences
special_considerations.length_constraint_evaluation: Assess whether brevity reflects genuine clarity about learning process or inadequate development of ideas
